name: Bald Eagle
description: The national bird of the United States, known for its striking white head and powerful talons capable of exerting 400 pounds of pressure per square inch.

name: Grizzly Bear
description: One of North America's most powerful predators, capable of running at 35 mph despite weighing up to 800 pounds.

name: American Alligator
description: A conservation success story that bounced back from near extinction. Their jaws can snap shut with nearly 3,000 pounds of force.

name: Monarch Butterfly
description: Famous for its epic 3,000-mile migration from Canada to Mexico, navigating using the sun and Earth's magnetic field.

name: American Bullfrog
description: The largest frog in North America, with a booming call that can be heard up to half a mile away. It will eat almost anything it can fit in its mouth.

name: Mountain Lion
description: Also called cougar, puma, or panther, this stealthy cat holds the Guinness record for the animal with the most names — over 40 in English alone.

name: Eastern Diamondback Rattlesnake
habitat: Pine flatwoods, coastal scrub, palmetto thickets
description: The largest venomous snake in North America, capable of delivering a massive dose of hemotoxic venom through fangs up to an inch long.

name: Brook Trout
habitat: Cold, clear streams and mountain lakes
description: The only trout native to much of the eastern US, adorned with beautiful vermiculations and bright red spots ringed in blue.

name: Black Widow Spider
description: Pound for pound, her venom is 15 times stronger than a rattlesnake's. The iconic red hourglass warns predators to stay away.

name: Wild Turkey
description: Benjamin Franklin lobbied for this bird over the Bald Eagle as the national symbol. Despite their bulk, wild turkeys can fly at speeds up to 55 mph.

name: Gray Wolf
region: Northern Rocky Mountains, Great Lakes, Alaska
description: Once nearly eliminated from the lower 48 states, wolves were reintroduced to Yellowstone in 1995, triggering a famous trophic cascade that reshaped the landscape.

name: Gila Monster
description: One of only two venomous lizards in North America. Its venom contains a compound now used in a diabetes medication.

name: Peregrine Falcon
description: The fastest animal on Earth, reaching speeds over 240 mph in a hunting dive called a stoop. They've adapted to nest on skyscrapers in major cities.

name: Hellbender
description: North America's largest salamander, reaching over two feet long. Also called 'snot otter' and 'devil dog,' it breathes entirely through its wrinkly skin.

name: Largemouth Bass
description: The most popular game fish in America, responsible for a multi-billion dollar fishing industry. Males guard the nest and protect fry for weeks after hatching.

name: Luna Moth
description: This ethereal green moth has no mouth and cannot eat as an adult — it lives only about one week, solely to find a mate.

name: American Bison
description: The largest land animal in North America, once numbering 60 million before being hunted to near extinction. They can jump six feet vertically from a standstill.

name: Coral Snake
habitat: Pine and scrub oak sandhills, hardwood hammocks
description: Possesses the second most potent venom of any snake in the world. The rhyme 'red touches yellow, kills a fellow' distinguishes it from harmless mimics.

name: Great Blue Heron
description: Standing four feet tall with a six-foot wingspan, this patient hunter strikes with lightning speed, spearing fish and even small mammals with its dagger-like bill.

name: Brown Recluse Spider
description: Identifiable by its violin-shaped marking, its necrotic venom can cause tissue death in severe bites. Despite its reputation, it bites only when pressed against skin.

name: Red-tailed Hawk
description: The most common hawk in North America. Its piercing screech is Hollywood's go-to raptor sound — often dubbed over Bald Eagle footage.

name: Wolverine
description: Fearless and ferocious relative of the weasel, known to drive bears and wolves off kills. Can travel 15 miles a day through deep snow.

name: Timber Rattlesnake
description: One of the snakes believed to have inspired the 'Don't Tread on Me' flag. They can sense temperature differences as small as 0.003°C with their heat-sensing pits.

name: Red Salamander
description: This brilliant red amphibian mimics the toxic red eft stage of eastern newts to fool predators. It can live over 20 years in the wild.

name: Paddlefish
description: A living fossil virtually unchanged for 300 million years, predating dinosaurs. Its paddle-shaped snout detects weak electrical fields to locate plankton.

name: Firefly
description: Their bioluminescent glow is the most efficient light source on Earth — nearly 100% of the energy is emitted as light with almost no heat.

name: Moose
description: The largest member of the deer family, standing up to seven feet at the shoulder. They are surprisingly strong swimmers and can dive up to 20 feet underwater to feed.

name: Horned Lizard
description: When threatened, this spiky lizard can shoot blood from its eyes up to five feet as a defense mechanism. The blood tastes foul to canine and feline predators.

name: Great Horned Owl
description: Called the 'tiger of the sky,' it has a grip strength of 300 psi and is the only animal that regularly preys on skunks. Its asymmetric ears allow pinpoint sound location.

name: Arizona Bark Scorpion
description: The most venomous scorpion in North America, it can climb walls and even ceilings. It glows bright blue-green under ultraviolet light.

name: American Black Bear
description: The most common bear in North America, with an incredible sense of smell seven times better than a bloodhound's. They can run uphill at 35 mph.

name: Copperhead
description: Responsible for more venomous snakebites in the US than any other species, though its venom is relatively mild. Its copper-banded camouflage is nearly perfect among leaf litter.

name: Spring Peeper
description: Tiny enough to sit on a dime, their deafening spring chorus can reach 90 decibels. They survive winter by freezing solid and thawing out in spring.

name: Alligator Gar
description: A prehistoric giant that can grow over eight feet long and breathe air. Its diamond-shaped scales were once used by Native Americans as arrowheads.

name: Praying Mantis
description: The only insect that can rotate its head 180 degrees to scan surroundings. Its strike takes just 50 milliseconds — faster than a human can blink.

name: Pronghorn
region: Western Great Plains, Rocky Mountain states
description: The fastest land animal in the Western Hemisphere at 55 mph, evolved to outrun the now-extinct American cheetah. They have 10x magnification vision.

name: Snapping Turtle
description: Prehistoric in appearance with a bite force strong enough to sever fingers. They spend so much time motionless that algae grows on their shells as camouflage.

name: Ruby-throated Hummingbird
description: Beats its wings 53 times per second and is the only bird that can fly backwards. It migrates 500 miles nonstop across the Gulf of Mexico.

name: Tiger Salamander
description: The largest land-dwelling salamander in North America, spending most of its life underground. Some populations become permanently aquatic, retaining their larval gills.

name: Channel Catfish
description: Has over 100,000 taste buds covering its entire body, essentially tasting with its skin. It can detect a single drop of substance in an Olympic-sized pool.

name: Dragonfly
description: An aerial predator with a 95% hunting success rate — the highest of any predator on Earth. Each compound eye contains nearly 30,000 individual lenses.

name: Bobcat
description: The most abundant wildcat in North America, thriving from swamps to suburbs. It can leap 12 feet to catch birds in mid-flight.

name: California Condor
habitat: Rocky cliffs, open grasslands, oak savanna
description: With a 9.5-foot wingspan, it's the largest flying bird in North America. Reduced to just 22 birds in 1987, a captive breeding program saved it from extinction.

name: Cottonmouth
habitat: Swamps, marshes, drainage ditches, lake edges
description: The only semi-aquatic viper in the world, named for the white interior of its mouth displayed as a threat. Unlike most snakes, it stands its ground rather than fleeing.

name: American Toad
description: A single toad can eat up to 1,000 insects per day, making it a gardener's best friend. Its skin secretions are mildly toxic to predators but harmless to humans.

name: Muskellunge
habitat: Clear lakes and large rivers with vegetation
description: Called the 'fish of 10,000 casts' for how difficult it is to catch, this apex predator of freshwater can exceed 50 pounds and strike with explosive ambush speed.

name: Cicada Killer Wasp
description: One of the largest wasps in North America at two inches long, it paralyzes cicadas mid-flight and carries them back to its burrow to feed its larvae.

name: River Otter
description: Playful and social, they slide down muddy and snowy banks for fun. They can hold their breath for up to eight minutes and close their ears and nostrils underwater.

name: Roadrunner
description: Can sprint at 20 mph and is fast enough to catch and kill rattlesnakes by bashing them against rocks. It reabsorbs water from its own feces to survive the desert.

name: Tarantula Hawk Wasp
description: Delivers the second most painful insect sting on the Schmidt Pain Index. It hunts tarantulas twice its size, paralyzing them to serve as live food for its larvae.
